Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Rapid Acquisition and Analysis of Complex Spectra with High-Speed Digitizers
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research at Undergraduate Institutions (RUI) award from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program in the Division of Chemistry, with co-funding from the Computer and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering (CDS&E) and Planetary Astronomy Programs, supports Professor Steven T. Shipman and his students at New College of Florida as they develop new tools that will help scientists analyze data from the atmospheres of planets, including our own and large clouds of molecules in space. The new tools are based on high-speed electronics that allow scientists to collect significantly more information about their samples than was previously possible. Software is being developed that takes advantage of these high-speed data-collectors and uses new computing techniques to process the influx of data. All the work is being performed by undergraduate students working with the principal investigator. The new software will be publicly shared.

The investigators are using new high-speed digitizers along with grid computing techniques to rapidly acquire and analyze rotational spectra of molecules of relevance to interstellar and atmospheric chemistry at temperatures ranging from roughly 250 to 325 K. In this temperature range, rotational spectra are extremely complex due to contributions from large amplitude motion and thermally-populated excited vibrational and conformational states. A new digitizer with a nearly 8000x speed advantage over current instrumentation is being used in conjunction with temperature-dependent and microwave-microwave double resonance measurements to automatically determine lower state energies and energy level connectivities of a large number of peaks in observed spectra. Software that is being developed, based on genetic algorithms and other approaches, will use this information to greatly ease the spectral assignment process. These algorithms will be ported to a grid computing platform to take maximum advantage of their parallelism and to further reduce the spectral analysis time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The core goals of this award were to use the increasing capabilities of modern hardware and computing to expand our capabilities to collect and analyze rotational spectra, with a focus on the spectra of molecules collected at or near room temperature. We also had a particular focus on making this type of science more accessible to undergraduate students who often have less time to spend in the lab than graduate students or post-docs.

On the hardware front, we successfully incorporated a real-time digitizer into our spectrometer design. This drastically increased the speed with which we take data. In particular, we were able to reach and sustain speed improvements in the data collection by a factor of 1600 (80 kHz vs 50 Hz repetition rates); what used to be a nearly 4.5 hour measurement can now be made in a mere 10 seconds. In addition to speeding up routine data collection, this also allowed us to start thinking about routinely performing more intricate measurements that could reveal additional information about the system and make it easier to fully understand the molecules under study. These kinds of measurements (such as taking spectra every 5 degrees from a temperature of -20 C to +40 C or performing large numbers of double-resonance measurements) were not previously possible due to the lengths of time required for each measurement with the slower digitizer.

Faster data collection then highlighted the next bottleneck, which was data analysis. Over the course of the award, we experimented with several different software-based approaches to automate tedious parts of the analysis. A cloud-computing based approach using the Amazon EC2 cloud computing platform was roughly 10x faster than running code on desktop machines, but students had a very difficult time using the software and Amazon's tweaks to their platform during the life of this award made it difficult to guarantee that the code would continue to work reliably. So, we returned to the slower desktop-based approach, but wrote a new version of the software that was simpler to use by students because it required far less user input. Using that software, a team of undergraduates was able to successfully collect and analyze the spectrum of eugenol, the primary molecule found in clove oil.

Our software development is still ongoing, and there are clear future paths for both how to make it run more efficiently and how to incorporate information from the more complicated experiments that we can now perform routinely with the real-time digitizer into the automated analysis process.
